skills.name: Given the properties of a polygon identify a corresponding diagram
Identify the number of vertices in 2D shapes
Complete a shape to have given attributes

explanations.A: Remember, reflex angles are angles too! Count carefully, which figure does NOT have four angles?
explanations.B: Read carefully! The question is looking for the figure that does NOT have four angles. Which figure does not have four angles?
explanations.C: Read carefully! The question is looking for the figure that does NOT have four angles. Which figure does not have four angles?
explanations.D: This figure is a pentagon and has 5 angles.

explanations.A: Read carefully! The question is looking for the figure that does NOT have five angles. Which figure does not have five angles?
explanations.B: This figure is a quadrilateral and has 4 angles.
explanations.C: Remember, reflex angles are angles too! Count carefully, which figure does NOT have five angles?
explanations.D: Read carefully! The question is looking for the figure that does NOT have five angles. Which figure does not have five angles?

explanations.A: We are creating a rhombus, so opposite sides need to be parallel to each other. Option A is located in the wrong direction from the vertex shown to create a parallel side.
explanations.B: Our shape will be a rhombus, which has diagonals that bisect each other. If we count down from our vertex 3 units, we reach the bisection point. Where will we be located if we continue to count down an additional 3 units?
explanations.C: From the vertex to the bisection of the diagonals is 3 units, so the correct location would be an additional 3 units down to location C.
explanations.D: I think you may have gone a bit too far. We are creating a rhombus, which has diagonals that bisect each other. How can you use that find the correct location?

explanations.A: Our shape will be a rhombus, which has diagonals that bisect each other. If we count up from our vertex 3 units, we reach the bisection point. Where will we be located if we continue to count up an additional 3 units?
explanations.B: From the vertex to the bisection of the diagonals is 3 units, so the correct location would be an additional 3 units up to location B.
explanations.C: We are creating a rhombus, so opposite sides need to be parallel to each other. Option C is located in the wrong direction from the vertex shown to create a parallel side.
explanations.D: I think you may have gone a bit too far. We are creating a rhombus, which has diagonals that bisect each other. How can you use that find the correct location?

explanations.A: I think you may have assumed 4 sides meant 4 equal sides, but that isn't the case.
explanations.B: Read carefully! This question is what the two figures do NOT have in common.
explanations.C: Careful! Both shapes have 4 equal, 90 degree angles. What do they NOT have in common?
explanations.D: The two figures do not have 4 equal side lengths.

explanations.A: Careful! Both shapes do have 4 sides. What do they NOT have in common?
explanations.B: Careful! Both shapes do have 4 angles. What do they NOT have in common?
explanations.C: The square has 4 equal angles, but the rhombus does not.
explanations.D: Careful! Both shapes do have 4 equal sides. What do they NOT have in common?

explanations.A: I think you may have forgotten that a side was already provided to you. How could you adjust your answer to account for the given side?
explanations.B: With the side provided, you will need 5 more sides to create a shape with 6 sides and therefore, 6 angles.
explanations.C: I think you got confused by the make up of an angle. Think about a triangle. How many side lengths does it have? How many angles? Now a square. How many side lengths does it have? How many angles? Do you notice a pattern? How could you apply that to this problem with 6 angles?
explanations.D: Think about a triangle. How many side lengths does it have? How many angles? Now a square. How many side lengths does it have? How many angles? Do you notice a pattern? How could you apply that to this problem with 6 angles?

explanations.A: I think you got confused by the make up of an angle. Think about a triangle. How many side lengths does it have? How many angles? Now a square. How many side lengths does it have? How many angles? Do you notice a pattern? How could you apply that to this problem with 5 angles?
explanations.B: I think you may have forgotten that a side was already provided to you. How could you adjust your answer to account for the given side?
explanations.C: Think about a triangle. How many side lengths does it have? How many angles? Now a square. How many side lengths does it have? How many angles? Do you notice a pattern? How could you apply that to this problem with 5 angles?
explanations.D: With the side provided, you will need 4 more sides to create a shape with 5 sides and therefore, 5 angles.

explanations.A: I think you may have added the side lengths of the two figures together, but we are looking for the number of angles. Try drawing a sketch of the triangle connected to the square to help!
explanations.B: It looks like you added the side lengths of the two figures together, subtracting 1 for the shared side, but that doesn't give us the angles. Try drawing a sketch of the triangle connected to the square. Does that help you see the number of angles better?
explanations.C: When the triangle and the square share an edge they form a pentagon. Two sets of angles are shared: (4+3) - 2 = 5 angles.
explanations.D: I think you got confused. Yes, we are adding two shapes together, but they are sharing an edge, which means they are also sharing some angles. Try sketching a picture. How many angles does your new shape have?

explanations.A: I think you got confused. Yes, we are adding two shapes together, but they are sharing an edge, which means they are also sharing some angles. Try sketching a picture. How many angles does your new shape have?
explanations.B: When the triangle and the pentagon share an edge, both two sets of angles are shared. (3+5) - 2 = 6 angles.
explanations.C: It looks like you added the side lengths of the two figures together, subtracting 1 for the shared side, but that doesn't give us the angles. Try drawing a sketch of the triangle connected to the pentagon. Does that help you see the number of angles better?
explanations.D: I think you may have added the side lengths of the two figures together, but we are looking for the number of angles. Try drawing a sketch of the triangle connected to the pentagon to help!
